1. Restatement of My Position  
I maintain that every person in the Room of the Dreaming enters a self-contained, trance-induced fantasy shaped by their own mind. Unger’s role is simply to induce and maintain the trance; he does not telepathically project a single shared sequence.  

2. Textual Evidence for Individual Dreams  
  a. Distinct Visions by Each Subject  
    • Johnson alone “sees a space ship” (II). He explicitly notes his vision disappears under the Siren‐like whirring and “goes into muted silence” when he cannot maintain focus (II). If all shared Unger’s dream, others could not resume it merely by “breaking contact with my dream” (II).  
    • Caldwell’s lab vision: upon “waking” he blurts “I was back in the lab on Earth” (III). A purely shared dream could not yield a divergence so radical as lab machinery to one at random.  
    • Vee Vee’s fear/faintness: she “never made the same mistake twice” (I) and breaks the trance to protect Johnson, showing she has agency over *her* dream state.  

  b. Personal Stimuli Interrupt Trance Privately  
    • Vee Vee’s Karmer grip and Johnson’s movement “breaks contact with my dream” (II). She alone “breaks contact” and later “I was watching something else” (II). An external collapse of Unger only occurs much later, yet individuals drop out sporadically before Unger floats (“some of them are already gone” (II)). If shared, they would all awaken only when Unger collapses.  

3. The Function of Hypnosis and Sensory Manipulation  
  a. “Wild frantic beat,” “Perfume of the Dreamer,” “Karmer nerve paralysis” (I) and “unknown nerve center” (II) strongly resemble hypnotic or pharmacological induction. In psychology, such inductions yield *subjective* visions reflecting personal memories, not a uniform broadcast. Johnson’s space‐flight fantasies originate from his childhood model-ships (II).  
  b. The “high-speed whirring” that specifically “stops” Johnson’s vision (II) and his struggle to hold *his* dream confirm an *internal* process vulnerable to interference, not a resilient external projection.  

4. Critique of Shared Dream Theory  
  a. Inconsistent Onset and Termination  
    • “Some of them are already gone” (II) before Unger’s levitation. If Unger projected levitation as the shared climax, observers would not exit *before* it emerges.  
    • Only Johnson remains fully “wide awake” (II) in “enormous chill,” able to see the spaceship. His “chill” is physiological fear from loss of expected personal dream, not from seeing “real” levitation. The “adrenals,” “pancreas,” and “thyroid” voices (III) are panic responses to unexpected sensory deprivation, not signs of perceiving an external reality.  

  b. Implausibility of Mass Telepathy  
    • No mechanism: Unger “weighs three hundred pounds,” “clad in a long robe” and merely sleeps on a *mat* (I) before floating. He lacks any visible apparatus or ritual to beam a dream beyond music and perfume. The narrative treats his levitation as part of an *individual* trance climax, not a telepathic amplifier.  
    • Realism in Zit-gun Defense: Johnson and Caldwell use “zit guns” to rouse only nearby Venusians. If they truly disrupted a communal dream, why must they physically gun down every Venusian? A shared illusion would vanish en masse once Unger is felled. Instead each Venusian must be physically incapacitated “endless number of them” (III).  

5. Why Debater_A’s Position Fails  
  a. Lack of Uniform Reaction to Levitation  
    • If levitation were the shared dream, why does Vee Vee *flee* from the mat and hide behind Johnson (II)? She calls it a vision to be “watched,” yet retreats when Unger floats (II), as if witnessing someone else’s private hallucination threatens her.  
  b. Delay and Individual Awakening  
    • After Unger falls, many Venusians *remain* unconscious or inert until Caldwell and Johnson “spray corvel gas” (III). If they had been merely dreaming, the collapse of Unger would itself awaken them without violence.  
  c. Contradictory Biological Cues  
    • Shared dream advocates cite Johnson’s physiological responses, but all stress reactions—sweat, adrenalin—are consistent with *withdrawal* from a chemically induced trance, as with drug users coming out of narcosis.  

6. Logical Coherence of “Individual Dreams”  
  • Each observer’s mind customizes the hypnotic stimuli into personally relevant visions (spaceship, lab, protective Carrier like Vee Vee).  
  • Individuals have free will to enter or exit their dreams, “breaking contact” at distinct times.  
  • Only Johnson, trained to resist, stays lucid long enough to “real” test Unger’s collapse, then must physically clear others.  

Conclusion  
The variable onset and termination of trance, the diversity of dream content, the need to physically subdue each Venusian, and the text’s repeated language of “my dream” confirm that *each* participant has *their own* individualized vision. Recognizing this fully explains the narrative events—unlike the untenable hypothesis of a single shared telepathic dream.
